panels.description:
# Active applications on root Marathon

## What does it mean
This metric shows the number of active applications in the root Marathon.

## Expected behavior
The number should be relatively stable unless services are being actively deployed/removed.

## Where to look when for further information:
Following metrics can provide additional information:

 * `marathon_instances_running`
 * `marathon.instances_staged`
 * `marathon_mesos_offers`

targets.legendFormat: Number of active apps on root Marathon

panels.title: Active applications running on root Marathon

panels.description:
# Active pods on root Marathon

## What does it mean
This metric shows the number of active pods in the root Marathon.

## Expected behavior
The number should be relatively stable unless services are being actively deployed/removed.

## Where to look when for further information:
Following metrics can provide additional information:

 * `marathon_instances_running`
 * `marathon_instances_staged`
 * `marathon_mesos_offers`

targets.legendFormat: Number of active pods on root Marathon

panels.title: Active pods running on root Marathon

panels.description:
# Active deployments on root Marathon

### What does it mean
This metric shows the number of active deployments in the root Marathon. 
A deployment happens when an app/pod was just created/updated and instances have to be started/killed. 

### Expected behavior
The number should usually be < 50, however, if the number of deployments is > 80 for a long period,
then it might be a signal that something is wrong.

### Where to look when for further information:
Following metrics can provide additional information:

 * `marathon_mesos_offers_incoming_counter`
 * `marathon_mesos_offers_declined_counter`
 * `marathon_mesos_offers_used_counter`
 * `marathon_mesos_calls_revive_counter`
 * `marathon_mesos_calls_suppress_counter`

targets.legendFormat: Number of active deployments on root Marathon

panels.title: Active deployments on root Marathon

panels.description:
# Staged instances on root Marathon

### What does it mean
This metric shows the number of staged instances in the root Marathon. An instance is staged when Marathon has sent a launch request to Mesos but it's not yet running.

### Expected behavior
This metric shouldn't have a large value, one can expect it to be < 10, however sometimes it might reach high values. 
If there are many staged instances, that might indicate a problem with an agent (docker daemon hangs, the image can't be pulled, etc.).

### Where to look when for further information
Following metrics can provide additional information:

 * `marathon_mesos_task_updates_task_error`
 * `marathon_mesos_task_updates_task_error_counter`

targets.legendFormat: Number of staged instances on root Marathon

panels.title: Staged instances on root Marathon

panels.description:
# Running instances on root Marathon

### What does it mean
This metric shows the number of running instances in the root Marathon. 

### Expected behavior
This metric shouldn't have huge drops unless apps/pods being upscaled/downscaled.

### Where to look when for further information:
Following metrics can provide additional information:

 * `marathon_mesos_offers`

targets.legendFormat: Number of running instances on root Marathon

panels.title: Running instances on root Marathon

panels.description:
# Launch overdue instances on root Marathon

### What does it mean
This metrics shows the number of overdue instances. Overdue instances are those that have been either launched or staged but hasn’t become running within the `task_launch_timeout` or `task_launch_confirm_timeout` respectively.

### Expected behavior
This metric should be around 0 at all times. 

### Where to look when for further information
The next metrics can provide additional information:

 * `marathon_mesos_task_updates_task_error`
 * `marathon_mesos_task_updates_task_error_counter`

targets.legendFormat: Number of overdue instances on root Marathon

panels.title: Launch overdue instances on root Marathon

panels.description:
# Uptime and leadership duration of root Marathon masters

### What does it mean
These metric shows the uptime of each root Marathon master and how long a given Marathon master stayed the leader.

### Expected behavior
This value should be linearly increasing over time. If there is a drop, that means that Marathon was restarted. If there are multiple drops within a short period of time that can be a sign of instability. 
Both, leadership duration and uptime should look the same since Marathon will restart upon leadership loss.
panels.title: Marathon uptime and leader duration

panels.description:
# Mesos offers metrics

### Incoming offers
Offers that marathon received from Mesos. If this value is low, then Marathon experiences an "offer starvation" unless a `suppress` call was issued.
panels.title: Mesos offers overview

panels.description:
# Mesos offers metrics

### Used offers
This metric shows the number of used Mesos offers. If Marathon is trying to deploy a service and receives enough incoming offers but doesn't seem to use any, then this usually means that the offers aren't a fit (bad role, not enough cpu/mem other resources, etc.)
panels.title: Used Mesos offers

panels.description:
# Mesos offers metrics

### Revive calls
If Marathon issues a `Revive` call, Mesos will start sending offers.
panels.title: Revive calls by root Marathon ($min_interval)

panels.description:
# Mesos offers metrics

### Suppress calls
If Marathon issues a `suppress` call, Mesos won't send any offers.
panels.title: Supress Mesos calls issued by root Marathon

panels.description:
# Marathon HTTP Metrics

## Request duration

This metric shows 95 percentile request duration. High numbers mean that marathon is experiencing quite some load.
panels.title: HTTP request duration p95

panels.description:
# Marathon HTTP Metrics

## HTTP request size

These metrics show the size of Marathon requests. Too high values can lead to Marathon being overloaded with data serialization.
panels.title: HTTP request size rate

panels.description:
# Marathon HTTP Metrics

## HTTP response size

These metrics show the size of Marathon responses. Too high values can lead to Marathon being overloaded with data serialization.
panels.title: HTTP response size rate

panels.description:
# Marathon HTTP Metrics

## HTTP response 2xx rates

This metric shows the rate of requests which resulted in status 200-299.
panels.title: HTTP response 2xx rates

panels.description:
# Marathon HTTP Metrics

## HTTP response 5xx rates

This metric shows the rate of requests which resulted in status 500-599. A short period of 5xx responses is expected in situations such as leader re-election.
panels.title: HTTP response 5xx error rates

panels.description:
# Marathon JVM Metrics

## Heap Usage

This metric shows Marathons heap usage. An overall growth pattern where more and more heap is being used can be an indication of a problem.
panels.title: Marathon heap usage

panels.description:
# Marathon JVM Metrics

## Total Memory Usage

This metric shows total Marathons memory usage. An overall growth pattern where more and more heap is being used can be an indication of a problem.
panels.title: Marathon total memory usage

panels.description:
# Marathon JVM Metrics

## Active Thread Count

This metric total number of active (and runnable) threads used by Marathon. A sudden change in the number of threads can be an indication of a problem.
panels.title: Marathon active and runnable threads count

panels.description:
# Marathon JVM Metrics

## Waiting Thread Count

This metric total number of waiting (and timed waiting) threads used by Marathon. A sudden change in the number of threads can be an indication of a problem.
panels.title: Marathon waiting and timed waiting threads count
